org.jtrim.access

Class DelegatedAccessToken<IDType>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim.access.DelegatedAccessToken<IDType>
  • Type Parameters:
    IDType - the type of the access ID (see getAccessID())
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AccessToken<IDType>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ScheduledAccessToken

    public class DelegatedAccessToken<IDType>
extends java.lang.Object
implements AccessToken<IDType>
    An AccessToken implementation which delegates all of its methods to another AccessToken specified at construction time.

    This implementation does not declare any methods other than the ones AccessToken offers but implements all of them by forwarding to another AccessToken implementation specified at construction time.

    This class was designed for two reasons:

    • To allow a safer way of class inheritance, so there can be no unexpected dependencies on overridden methods. To imitate inheritance subclass DelegatedAccessToken: specify the AccessToken you want to "subclass" in the constructor and override the required methods or provide new ones.
    • To hide other public methods of an AccessToken from external code. This way, the external code can only access methods which the AccessToken interface provides.

    Thread safety

    The thread safety properties of this class entirely depend on the wrapped AccessToken instance.

    Synchronization transparency

    If instances of this class are synchronization transparent or if its synchronization control can be observed by external code entirely depends on the wrapped AccessToken instance.

    • Field Detail

      • wrappedToken

        protected final AccessToken<IDType> wrappedToken
        The AccessToken to which the methods are forwarded. This field can never be null because the constructor throws NullPointerException if null was specified as the AccessToken.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DelegatedAccessToken

        public DelegatedAccessToken(AccessToken<IDType> token)
        Initializes the wrappedToken field with the specified argument.
        Parameters:
        token - the AccessToken to which the methods are forwarded. This argument cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified AccessToken is null

    • Method Detail

      • getAccessID

        public IDType getAccessID()
        Returns an ID of the request used to create this AccessToken instance.

        Note that this ID does not need to be unique but cannot be null. The ID is intended to be used to provide information about this access, so a client can determine if it should cancel this token to allow a new token to be created which conflicts with this token.

        Thread safety
        Implementations of this method required to be completely thread-safe without any further synchronization.
        Synchronization transparency
        Implementations of this method required to be synchronization transparent.
        Specified by:
        getAccessID in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Returns:
        the ID of the request used to create this AccessToken instance. This method always returns the same object for a given AccessToken instance and never returns null.
        See Also:
        AccessRequest

      • createExecutor

        public org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutor createExecutor(org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutor executor)
        Creates a TaskExecutor backed by the specified TaskExecutor which will not execute tasks after this AccessToken was released.

        The returned executor is useful to execute tasks which may only be executed if this AccessToken is not released. It is guaranteed, that this AccessToken will not be released while a task submitted to the returned TaskExecutor is currently executing.

        Note that cleanup tasks are always executed, even if this AccessToken has already been released.

        Specified by:
        createExecutor in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Parameters:
        executor - the TaskExecutor which will actually execute tasks submitted to the returned TaskExecutor. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a TaskExecutor backed by the specified TaskExecutor which will not execute tasks after this AccessToken was released.

      • addReleaseListener

        public org.jtrim.event.ListenerRef addReleaseListener(java.lang.Runnable listener)
        Registers a new listener which will be notified if this AccessToken was released. When the listener is notified, AccessToken.isReleased() already returns true.

        The listener is notified even if it has been released prior to adding the listener and the listener is never notified more than once.

        Registering the same listener twice is allowed and will cause that listener to be notified as many times as it have been registered to be notified of the release of this access token.

        Note that the listener must be very agnostic about on which thread it can be called. It is perfectly allowed for an implementation to notify the listener in this method invocation.

        Unregistering the listener
        Unlike the general removeXXX idiom in Swing listeners, this listener can be removed using the returned reference.

        The unregistering of the listener is not necessary and in general implementations of AccessToken are required to no longer reference the registered listeners.

        Specified by:
        addReleaseListener in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to be registered to be notified when this AccessToken has been released. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the reference to the newly registered listener which can be used to remove this newly registered listener, so it will no longer be notified of the release event. Note that this method may return an unregistered listener if this AccessToken has already been released. This method never returns null.

      • isReleased

        public boolean isReleased()
        Checks whether this AccessToken has lost access to the associated resources or not. That is, if the executors of this AccessToken will execute submitted tasks or not.

        In case this method returns true, it is guaranteed that, no more tasks will be executed by executors of this AccessToken, and no tasks are currently being executed.

        Specified by:
        isReleased in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Returns:
        true if this AccessToken has lost access to the associated resources, false otherwise

      • release

        public void release()
        Prevents the executors of this AccessToken to execute tasks submitted after this call. When all the previously submitted tasks finish, notifies the release listeners.

        This method will prevent execution of tasks even on TaskExecutor instances created after this method call.

        Specified by:
        release in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        See Also:
        AccessToken.addReleaseListener(Runnable)

      • releaseAndCancel

        public void releaseAndCancel()
        Prevents the executors of this AccessToken to execute tasks submitted after this call and cancels the already submitted tasks. When there are no more tasks currently executing (and there will be no more), notifies the release listeners.

        This method will prevent execution of tasks even on TaskExecutor instances created after this method call.

        Specified by:
        releaseAndCancel in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        See Also:
        AccessToken.addReleaseListener(Runnable)

      • awaitRelease

        public void awaitRelease(org.jtrim.cancel.CancellationToken cancelToken)
        Waits until the executors of this AccessToken will not execute any more tasks. After this method returns (without throwing an exception), subsequent AccessToken.isReleased() method calls of the executors of this AccessToken will return true.

        After this method returns without throwing an exception, the rights associated with this AccessToken are available (unless acquired independently of this AccessToken). That is, if this AccessToken was created by an AccessManager, then the rights required to create this token are available again.

        Specified by:
        awaitRelease in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Parameters:
        cancelToken - the CancellationToken which can be used to stop waiting for the release event of this AccessToken. That is, if this method detects, that cancellation was requested, it will throw an OperationCanceledException. This argument cannot be null.
        See Also:
        AccessToken.addReleaseListener(Runnable)

      • tryAwaitRelease

        public boolean tryAwaitRelease(org.jtrim.cancel.CancellationToken cancelToken,
                      long timeout,
                      java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Waits until the executors of this AccessToken will not execute any more tasks or the given timeout elapses. After this method returns true, subsequent AccessToken.isReleased() method calls of the executors of this AccessToken will also return true.

        After this method returns true, the rights associated with this AccessToken are available (unless acquired independently of this AccessToken). That is, if this AccessToken was created by an AccessManager, then the rights required to create this token are available again.

        Specified by:
        tryAwaitRelease in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Parameters:
        cancelToken - the CancellationToken which can be used to stop waiting for the release event of this AccessToken. That is, if this method detects, that cancellation was requested, it will throw an OperationCanceledException. This argument cannot be null.
        timeout - the maximum time to wait for this AccessToken to be released in the given time unit. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        unit - the time unit of the timeout argument. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        true if this AccessToken has been released before the timeout elapsed, false if the timeout elapsed first. In case this code was released prior to this call this method always returns true.
        See Also:
        AccessToken.addReleaseListener(Runnable)

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • isExecutingInThis

        public boolean isExecutingInThis()
        Description copied from interface: AccessToken
        Returns true if the calling code is executing in the context of this access token. That is, it is executed by a task submitted to an executor created by the createExecutor method of this access token.

        This method can be used to check that a method call is executing in the context it was designed for.

        Specified by:
        isExecutingInThis in interface AccessToken<IDType>
        Returns:
        true if the calling code is executing in the context of this access token, false otherwise
